summary_points: 1. Brown & Brown, Inc. issued $4.2 billion in senior notes on June 23, 2025, with maturities ranging from 2026 to 2055, and interest rates from 4.6% to 6.25%.

2.  The net proceeds of approximately $4.2 billion (after deducting underwriting discounts and estimated offering expenses), along with proceeds from a prior common stock sale and cash on hand, will primarily fund the acquisition of RSC Topco, Inc.
3. Failure to consummate the RSC acquisition by the Outside Date (potentially June 10, 2026) would trigger mandatory redemption of most of the issued notes at 101% of principal plus accrued interest.
1. Keurig Dr Pepper Inc.'s June 18, 2025 annual meeting saw shareholder approval of all proposals, including the ratification of Deloitte & Touche LLP as auditors.
2.  The significant vote in favor of Deloitte & Touche (1.2 billion vs 3.5 million) suggests strong shareholder confidence.
3.  The one-year term for the newly elected directors necessitates another election in June 2026.
1. Everest Group, Ltd. expanded its Board of Directors to 11 members and appointed Allan Levine on June 23, 2025, granting him a $125,000 annual retainer and restricted shares worth $325,000.
2. Darryl Page, also elected to the Board on May 20, 2025, received a grant of restricted shares with a fair market value of $325,000 on June 23, 2025.
3.  The Board reorganized its committee structure on June 23, 2025, assigning Levine and Page to various committees.

1. Biogen Inc. held its 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders on June 17, 2025, where eleven nominees were elected to the Board of Directors, with varying levels of shareholder support ranging from 90,200,723 votes for Caroline D. Dorsa to 115,162,666 votes for Monish Patolawala.
2.  The advisory vote on executive compensation at Biogen's June 17, 2025, annual meeting received 78,531,756 votes for and 37,113,368 votes against.

3. PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP was ratified as Biogen Inc.'s independent registered public accounting firm for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025, receiving 120,065,433 votes for and 5,916,416 votes against.
1. UDR, Inc. appointed David D. Bragg as Senior Vice President - Chief Financial Officer, effective July 24, 2025, succeeding Joseph D. Fisher, who will become Chief Investment Officer.

2. Bragg's initial compensation package includes a $500,000 annual base salary, a target annual cash bonus of $750,000, a target long-term incentive award valued at $1,000,000, a $200,000 signing bonus, and a signing equity award valued at $2,000,000.
3. Bragg's $2,000,000 signing equity award will vest ratably over five years, contingent on continued employment.
1. On June 18, 2025, Medtronic plc expanded its Board of Directors from 10 to 11 members, appointing Dr. Joon Lee as a new director.
2.  A press release announcing Dr. Lee's appointment was issued on June 23, 2025.
3. Dr. Lee's compensation will be an annual cash retainer and director equity grant, as described in Medtronic's August 9, 2024, Definitive Proxy Statement.

1. On June 23, 2025, Verizon Communications Inc. announced the final results of its exchange offers for 10 series of notes, exchanging approximately $2.2 billion in principal amount of old notes for newly issued 5.401% Notes due 2037.
2.  Of the $300 million initially allocated to cash offers for old notes, the total was increased to $500 million and approximately $700 million in principal amount of notes were purchased for cash.

3.  The newly issued 5.401% Notes due 2037 will not be registered under the Securities Act or any state securities laws, meaning they cannot be offered or sold in the United States without registration or an exemption.
1. On June 21, 2025, FedEx founder and Executive Chairman Frederick W. Smith passed away, leading to the election of R. Brad Martin as the new Chairman of the Board on June 23, 2025.
2.  This 8-K filing reports no significant numerical changes in FedEx's financial performance.
3. The death of Frederick W. Smith may impact FedEx's long-term strategic direction and operational performance, although the precise effects remain uncertain.
1. On June 23, 2025, Super Micro Computer, Inc. announced a proposed offering of $2 billion in convertible senior notes due 2030, with an option to purchase an additional $300 million.
2. The company intends to use up to $200 million of the net proceeds to repurchase its own common stock.
3.  The offering's success and the impact of related derivative transactions on the company's stock price are subject to market conditions and other uncertainties.
1. FactSet's Q3 2025 GAAP revenues were $585.5 million, a 5.9% increase year-over-year, driven by wealth and institutional buy-side clients; however, GAAP diluted EPS decreased by 5.4% to $3.87.
2.  Organic ASV increased 4.5% year-over-year to $2,296.9 million as of May 31, 2025,  but operating margins decreased significantly (GAAP down 350 bps, adjusted down 270 bps) year-over-year.
3. FactSet's CEO, Phil Snow, will retire in early September 2025, to be succeeded by Sanoke Viswanathan; FactSet reaffirmed its fiscal 2025 guidance despite the margin decrease.

1.  Hormel Foods Corporation appointed Jeffrey M. Ettinger as Interim CEO and John F. Ghingo as President, effective July 14, 2025, following the previously announced retirement of James P. Snee on October 26, 2025.

2.  Mr. Ettinger's interim CEO compensation includes a $1,200,000 annual base salary, a $2,000,000 target annual incentive, and a one-time $7,200,000 equity grant, while Mr. Ghingo will receive an initial $730,000 annual base salary and a $3,200,000 annual long-term incentive target.
3. Mr. Ettinger's contract as Interim CEO expires October 25, 2026, while Mr. Ghingo's contract as President expires December 31, 2026, unless extended or terminated earlier.
